title: South Pacific Tourism Ministers released statement
text:
South Pacific Tourism Ministers released statement   
Oct 16, 2015 eTN   
The South Pacific Tourism Organisation (SPTO) 25th Council of Tourism Ministers met in Papeete, Tahiti, today. 
The Tahitian Minister for Tourism and International Air Transportation, Modernization of Administration and Public Service, and the Official Government Spokesperson and Public Service, Honorable Jean – Christophe Bouissou welcomed the Council members and urged the Council to consider tourism as a real opportunity and a major focus for the economic development of the South Pacific. 
The meeting of the Ministers was attended by the Honorable Henry Puna, Prime Minister and Minister for Tourism of Cook Islands; Honorable Rimeta Beniamina, Minister for Communications, Transport and Tourism Development of Kiribati; Honorable Dion Taufitu, Associate Minister for Tourism of Niue; Honorable Jean-Christophe Bouissou, Minister for Tourism of Tahiti; Honorable Etuate Sungalu Lavulavu, Minister for Infrastructure and Tourism of Tonga; Honorable Namoliki Sualiki Neemia, Minister of Home Affairs and Rural Development of Tuvalu; and David Vaeafe, Director for Tourism, American Samoa. The other government members were represented by proxies, which were China, Federated States of Micronesia, Fiji, Nauru, New Caledonia, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu. Hon. Jean-Christophe Bouissou, Minister for Tourism of Tahiti was elected as the new Chairman of the Council replacing the Honorable Etuate Lavulavu, the Minister of Tourism from Tonga. The Ministers discussed issues related to SPTO’s policies, activities, work programme and budget and heard presentations of the Pacific Cruise Tourism Development Strategy 2015-2019, the Association of South Pacific Airlines (ASPA) and the European Union supported Pacific Regional Tourism Capacity Building Programme implemented by the SPTO. The communique’ released by the Ministers included the approval of the 2016 SPTO Work Plan and Budget, Pacific Cruise Tourism Development Strategy (PCTDS) 2015-2019 and high level policies pertaining to the SPTO Constitution, as well as multi-lateral funding and support initiatives. In the spirit of regionalism, the Ministers encouraged member countries to work together, to pursue the sustainable development of the tourism sector for the longer term benefits of Pacific Island economies. 
The Ministers commended the advocacy efforts by SPTO and endorsed the activities undertaken at both regional and international levels, whilst also commending the initiatives to explore development support from the United Nations through the 10 Year Framework of Programme; and approved SPTO’s membership of the 10YFP Multi-Stakeholder Advisory Committee (MAC) on Sustainable Tourism.
